# A Deferred proofs 

Lemma 3.3 (Surrogate prices solve one-item nonobligatory inspection). For all $r \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\check{C}_{\text {item }}^{\mathrm{OI}}(r) & =\min \{c+\mathrm{E}[\min \{X, r\}, r]\}=\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{W^{\mathrm{OI}}, r\right\}\right] \\
\check{C}_{\text {item }}^{\mathrm{NI}}(r) & =\min \{c+\mathrm{E}[\min \{X, r\}, r, \mu]\}=\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{W^{\mathrm{NI}}, r\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. The obligatory inspection statement is standard (see, e.g., Kleinberg et al., 2016, Lemma 1), so we turn immediately to the nonobligatory inspection statement. We consider two cases:
Case 1: $u^{\text {rsv }}<u^{\text {bkp }}$. Expanding both sides using Definition 3.2, we aim to show

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, u^{\mathrm{bkp}}, r\right\}\right]=\min \left\{\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, r\right\}\right], \mu\right\}
$$

We clearly have

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, u^{\mathrm{bkp}}, r\right\}\right] \leq \mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, r\right\}\right]
$$

and using Definition 3.2 and the $u^{\text {rsv }}<u^{\text {bkp }}$ assumption, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, u^{\mathrm{bkp}}, r\right\}\right] & \leq \mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{\max \left\{X, u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right\}, u^{\mathrm{bkp}}\right\}\right] \\
& =\mu_{n}+\mathrm{E}\left[\left(u^{\mathrm{rsv}}-X\right)^{+}\right]-\mathrm{E}\left[\left(X-u^{\mathrm{bkp}}\right)^{+}\right] \\
& =\mu+c-c=\mu
\end{aligned}
$$

One of (A.2) or (A.3) holds with equality (because $r \leq u^{\text {bkp }}$ or $r \geq u^{\text {bkp }}$ ), implying (A.1).
Case 2: $u^{\text {rsv }} \geq u^{\text {bkp }}$. Expanding both sides using Definition 3.2, we aim to show

$$
\min \{\mu, r\}=\min \left\{\mu, \mathrm{E}\left[\min \left\{W^{\mathrm{OI}}, r\right\}\right]\right\}
$$

The left-hand side is greater than or equal to the right-hand side, so it remains only to show the reverse inequality. By Definition 3.2, we have $u^{\text {rsv }} \leq W^{\mathrm{OI}}$ with probability 1 , so it suffices to show $\mu \leq u^{\text {rsv }}$. This holds due to the $u^{\text {rsv }} \geq u^{\text {bkp }}$ assumption, (RP) and (BP), and the following computation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu=\mathrm{E}[X] & =u^{\mathrm{rsv}}+\mathrm{E}\left[\left(X-u^{\mathrm{rsv}}\right)^{+}\right]-\mathrm{E}\left[\left(u^{\mathrm{rsv}}-X\right)^{+}\right] \\
& \leq u^{\mathrm{rsv}}+\mathrm{E}\left[\left(X-u^{\mathrm{bkp}}\right)^{+}\right]-\mathrm{E}\left[\left(u^{\mathrm{rsv}}-X\right)^{+}\right] \\
& =u^{\mathrm{rsv}}+c-c=u^{\mathrm{rsv}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 3.4 (Single-item selection lower bound). In nonobligatory inspection single-item selection, the optimal policy's expected total cost satisfies

$$
\check{C}^{\mathrm{NI}}=\min _{\pi \in \Pi^{\mathrm{NI}}} \mathrm{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right] \geq \mathrm{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}}\right]
$$

Proof. Consider an arbitrary policy $\pi$ for the DM. After $t$ rounds, the policy has inspected some items and possibly selected one. Let ${ }^{7}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
C(t) & =\text { total inspection and selection cost paid by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
W_{n}(t) & = \begin{cases}0 & \text { if any item is selected by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
X_{n} & \text { if } n \text { is inspected, but not selected, by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
W_{n}^{\mathrm{Nl}} & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \\
I(t) & =\text { information } \pi \text { gains from inspections during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
K(t) & =C(t)+\mathrm{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W_{n}(t) \mid I(t)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

After $N+1$ rounds, the DM will have selected an item and the process will have terminated, so $K(N+1)=C^{\pi}$. We also have $K(0)=\mathrm{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W^{\mathrm{Nl}}\right]$, so it suffices to show that $\{K(t)\}_{t}$ is a submartingale with respect to $\{I(t)\}_{t}$.

Below, to reduce clutter, we abbreviate $\mathrm{E}[\cdot \mid I(t)]$ to $\mathrm{E}_{t}[\cdot]$.
We aim to show $K(t) \leq \mathrm{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]$. To do so, we consider each action the DM might take on each item $m \in[N]$. For each action, we write the difference $\mathrm{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t)$ in terms of the quantity

$$
R_{\# m}(t)=\min _{n \in[N] \backslash\{m\}} W_{n}(t)
$$

The fact that $R_{\# m}(t)$ depends only on $W_{n}(t)$ for $n \neq m$ implies the following observations.
(O1) If the DM takes an action on item $m$ at time $t$, then $R_{\# m}(t)=R_{\# m}(t+1)$.
(O2) $R_{\# m}(t)$ is conditionally independent of $W_{m}(t)$ given $I(t)$.
With the appropriate notation and the above observations in hand, we can show the difference $\mathrm{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t)$ is nonnegative no matter which action the DM takes.

- If item $m$ is closed and the DM inspects it, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t) & =-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\# m}(t)\right\}\right]+c_{m}+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{X_{m}, R_{\# m}(t+1)\right\}\right] \\
& =-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\# m}(t)\right\}\right]+c_{m}+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{X_{m}, R_{\# m}(t)\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equality follows by (O1), and its right-hand side is nonnegative by (O2) and Lemma 3.3.

- If item $m$ is closed and the DM selects it (without inspection), then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t) & =-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\# m}(t+1)\right\}\right]+\mu_{m} \\
& =-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\# m}(t)\right\}\right]+\mu_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Again, the second equality follows by (O1), and its right-hand side is nonnegative by (O2) and Lemma 3.3.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ Below, we allow $t$ to be greater than the number of rounds that $\pi$ takes to select an item. We follow the convention that the process simply remains static after an item is selected.

- If item $m$ is open and the DM selects it, then

$$
\mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t)=-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{X_{m}, R_{\# m}(t)\right\}\right]+X_{m}
$$

This is nonnegative because $X_{m}$ is known to the DM at time $t$, so $X_{m}=\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[X_{m}\right]$.
Theorem 5.2 (Combinatorial selection lower bound). Consider combinatorial selection with model $(\mathcal{F}, h)$ under nonobligatory inspection. The optimal policy's expected total cost satisfies

$$
\min _{\pi \in \Pi^{\mathrm{N}}(\mathcal{F}, h)} \mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right] \geq \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{N} 1}\right]
$$

Proof. This proof follows essentially the same steps as the proof of Theorem 3.4 above, but with some extra complications to handle the combinatorial aspect.

Consider an arbitrary policy $\pi$ for the DM. After $t$ rounds, the policy has inspected some items and possibly selected one. Let ${ }^{8}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
C(t) & =\text { total inspection and selection cost paid by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
W_{n}(t) & = \begin{cases}0 & \text { if any item is selected by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
X_{n} & \text { if } n \text { is inspected, but not selected, by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
W_{n}^{\mathrm{N} 1} & \text { otherwise, }\end{cases} \\
I(t) & =\text { information } \pi \text { gains from inspections during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\} \\
\mathcal{F}(t) & =\{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F} \mid \mathcal{S} \text { contains all items selected by } \pi \text { during }\{0, \ldots, t-1\}\} \\
Z(t) & =\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F}(t)}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S}} W_{n}(t)+h(\mathcal{S})\right) \\
K(t) & =C(t)+\mathbf{E}[Z(t) \mid I(t)]
\end{aligned}
$$

After $N+1$ rounds, the DM will have selected an item and the process will have terminated, so $K(N+1)=C^{\pi}$. We also have $K(0)=\mathbf{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W^{\mathrm{N} 1}\right]$, so it suffices to show that $\{K(t)\}_{t}$ is a submartingale with respect to $\{I(t)\}_{t}$.

Below, to reduce clutter, we abbreviate $\mathbf{E}[\cdot \mid I(t)]$ to $\mathbf{E}_{t}[\cdot]$.
We aim to show $K(t) \leq \mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]$. To do so, we consider each action the DM might take on each item $m \in[N]$. For each action, write the difference $\mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t)$ in terms of the quantities

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{\# m}(t) & =\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F}(t) \mid m \notin \mathcal{S}}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S}} W_{n}(t)+h(\mathcal{S})\right) \\
Q_{\# m}(t) & =\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F}(t) \mid m \in \mathcal{S}}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S} \backslash\{m\}} W_{n}(t)+h(\mathcal{S})\right) \\
R_{\# m}(t) & =P_{\# m}(t)-Q_{\# m}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ Below, we allow $t$ to be greater than the number of rounds that $\pi$ takes to select an admissible set of items. We follow the convention that the process simply remains static after such a set is selected.

We use the convention that a minimum over an empty set is $\infty$. That is, if all sets in $\mathcal{F}(t)$ contain $m$, then $P_{\neq m}(t)=\infty$, and similarly if none contain $m$, then $Q_{\neq m}(t)=\infty .{ }^{9}$

These quantities above give a useful decomposition of $Z(t)$, namely that for any item $m$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z(t) & =\min \left\{P_{\neq m}(t), Q_{\neq m}(t)+W_{m}(t)\right\} \\
& =Q_{\neq m}(t)+\min \left\{W_{m}(t), R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

The fact that $Q_{\neq m}(t)$ and $R_{\neq m}(t)$ depend only on $W_{n}(t)$ for $n \neq m$ implies the following observations.
(O1) If the DM takes an action on item $m$ at time $t$, then $P_{\neq m}(t) \leq P_{\neq m}(t+1)$ and $Q_{\neq m}(t)=$ $Q_{\neq m}(t+1)$, so $R_{\neq m}(t) \leq R_{\neq m}(t+1)$.
(O2) $R_{\neq m}(t)$ is conditionally independent of $W_{m}(t)$ given $\mathcal{I}(t)$.
With the appropriate notation and the above observations in hand, we can show the difference $\mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t)$ is nonnegative no matter which action the DM takes.

- If item $m$ is closed and the DM inspects it, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{t}[K( & (t+1)]-K(t) \\
& =-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t)+\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+c_{m}+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t+1)+\min \left\{X_{m}, R_{\neq m}(t+1)\right\}\right] \\
& \geq-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+c_{m}+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{X_{m}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality follows by (O1), and its right-hand side is nonnegative by (O2) and Lemma 3.3.

- If item $m$ is closed and the DM selects it (without inspection), then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t) \\
& \quad=-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t)+\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t+1)+\min \left\{\mu_{m}, \infty\right\}\right] \\
& \quad=-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+\mu_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equality follows by (O1), and its right-hand side is nonnegative by (O2) and Lemma 3.3. The infinity appears because $P_{\neq m}(t+1)=\infty$ due to $m$ being selected at time $t$.

- If item $m$ is open and the DM selects it, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{E}_{t}[K(t+1)]-K(t) \\
& \quad=-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t)+\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[Q_{\neq m}(t+1)+\min \left\{X_{m}, \infty\right\}\right] \\
& \quad=-\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\mathrm{Nl}}, R_{\neq m}(t)\right\}\right]+X_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equality follows by (O1), and its right-hand side is nonnegative because $X_{m}$ is known to the DM at time $t$, so $X_{m}=\mathbf{E}_{t}\left[X_{m}\right]$. Again, the infinity appears because $P_{\neq m}(t+1)=$ $\infty$ due to $m$ being selected at time $t$.

Theorem 5.4. Let $\pi \in \Pi^{\mathrm{OI}}(\mathcal{F}, h)$ be a policy for combinatorial obligatory inspection for a given combinatorial model $(\mathcal{F}, h)$. Suppose that for all hidden price distributions and inspection costs, $\pi$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ Provided the policy $\pi$ never fails to select a feasible set of items, it will never be the case that both $P_{\neq m}(t)$ and $Q_{\neq m}(t)$ are infinite.

satisfies $\mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right] \leq \beta \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{OI}}\right]$. Then for all hidden price distributions and inspection costs, if all items admit a local $\alpha$-approximation, then using $\mathrm{LH}[\pi]$ with the corresponding hedging probabilities yields expected cost bounded by

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[C^{\mathrm{LH}[\pi]}\right] \leq \alpha \beta \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{NI}}\right] \leq \alpha \beta \min _{\pi^{\prime} \in \Pi^{\mathrm{NI}}(\mathcal{F}, h)} \mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi^{\prime}}\right]
$$

In particular, $\mathrm{LH}[\pi]$ always yields a $\frac{4}{3} \beta$-approximation for combinatorial selection with nonobligatory inspection.

Proof. We actually show the following stronger result: if for each item, a local hedging probability exists giving a local $\alpha$-approximation (or better), then using those same local hedging probabilities makes $\mathrm{LH}[\pi]$ a $\alpha \beta$-approximation. This implies the theorem because by Theorem 4.3, such local hedging probabilities exist for some $\alpha<4 / 3$.

Because the second stage of $\mathrm{LH}[\pi]$ runs $\pi$, the fact that $\mathrm{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right] \leq \beta \mathrm{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{OI}}\right]$ implies

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[C^{\mathrm{LH}[\pi]}\right] \leq \beta \mathrm{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{LH}}\right]
$$

Combining this observation with Theorem 5.2, it suffices to show that for appropriately chosen local hedging probabilities, we have

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{LH}}\right] \leq \alpha \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{NI}}\right]
$$

Before proving (A.4) formally, let us outline the main idea, which is essentially a generalization of the proof of Theorem 4.4. Starting from $Z^{\mathrm{LH}}$ and replacing each item's LH -surrogate price with $\alpha$ times its NI -surrogate price one by one, resulting in $\alpha Z^{\mathrm{NI}}$. Because local hedging gives a local $\alpha$ approximation (Definition 4.2) for each item, each replacement only increases the expected value.

To formalize the above outline, we need notation for describing the replacement of surrogate prices one by one. To that end, let

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{n}^{(m)} & = \begin{cases}\alpha W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}} & \text { if } n \leq m \\
W_{n}^{\mathrm{LH}\left(p_{n}\right)} & \text { if } n>m\end{cases} \\
Z^{(m)} & =\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F}}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S}} W_{n}^{(m)}+h(\mathcal{S})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then it suffices to show $\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m-1)}\right] \leq \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m)}\right]$, as then

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{LH}}\right]=\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(0)}\right] \leq \cdots \leq \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(N)}\right]=\alpha \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{\mathrm{NI}}\right]
$$

where the equalities at either end follow from Definition 5.1.
To show $\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m-1)}\right] \leq \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m)}\right]$, the key idea is to split the minimization over $[N] \in \mathcal{F}$ into cases based on whether item $m$ is in the optimizing set. We therefore define

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{\neq m}=\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F} \mid m \in \mathcal{S}}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S}} W_{n}^{(m)}+h(\mathcal{S})\right) \\
& Q_{\neq m}=\min _{\mathcal{S} \in \mathcal{F} \mid m \in \mathcal{S}}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{S} \backslash\{m\}} W_{n}^{(m)}+h(\mathcal{S})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Because $W_{n}^{(m-1)}=W_{n}^{(m)}$ for all $n \neq m$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z^{(m-1)} & =\min \left\{P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}+W_{m}^{\operatorname{LH}\left(p_{m}\right)}\right\} \\
Z^{(m)} & =\min \left\{P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}+\alpha W_{m}^{\mathrm{N}}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note also that $P_{\neq m}$ and $Q_{\neq m}$ are independent of $W_{m}^{\operatorname{LH}\left(p_{m}\right)}$ and $W_{m}^{\mathrm{NI}}$, as they depend on the surrogate prices of all items except item $m$. Using this and the fact that local hedging gives a local $\alpha$-approximation for item $m$ (Definition 4.2), we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m-1)} \mid P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}\right] & =Q_{\neq m}+\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{m}^{\operatorname{LH}\left(p_{m}\right)}, P_{\neq m}-Q_{\neq m}\right\} \mid P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}\right] \\
& \leq Q_{\neq m}+\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{\alpha W_{m}^{\mathrm{NI}}, P_{\neq m}-Q_{\neq m}\right\} \mid P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}\right] \\
& =\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m)} \mid P_{\neq m}, Q_{\neq m}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies $\mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m-1)}\right] \leq \mathbf{E}\left[Z^{(m)}\right]$, as desired.

# B Alternative proof of the lower bound for single-item selection 

In this section, we give an alternative proof of Theorem 3.4 by reducing it to a result of Beyhaghi and Kleinberg (2019), which is a tighter lower bound on inf ${ }_{\pi} \mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right]$. The reason we do not directly use Beyhaghi and Kleinberg's result for our proof is that, as will soon become clear, their result is less explicit than Theorem 3.4. Rather than a single expression that works for all policies $\pi$, their result bounds $\mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right]$ using an expression which itself depends on $\pi$. But it is instructive to present their result and show how it implies our weaker but more explicit bound.

We note that although Beyhaghi and Kleinberg (2019) consider the reward-maximization setting instead of the cost-minimization setting, the definitions and proofs we consider in this section easily translate to the cost setting. We believe Beyhaghi and Kleinberg's approach could also be used to obtain a policy-dependent version of Theorem 5.2, but this is less immediate.

The main idea behind the approach Beyhaghi and Kleinberg (2019) take is this: to prove a policy-dependent bound, one should use a policy-dependent analogue of surrogate prices. One way of doing so is the following.

Definition B.1. Let $\pi$ be a policy for the nonobligatory inspection problem. The $\pi$-surrogate price of item $n$ is the random variable

$$
W_{n}^{\pi}= \begin{cases}W_{n}^{\mathrm{OI}} & \text { if } \pi \text { inspects item } n \\ \mu & \text { if } \pi \text { does not inspect item } n\end{cases}
$$

Unlike the other types of surrogate prices we consider, two different items' $\pi$-surrogate prices are not necessarily independent. This is because the hidden price revealed by inspecting one item may influence the decision of whether to inspect another. ${ }^{10}$ Despite this subtlety, Beyhaghi and Kleinberg (2019) use $\pi$-surrogate prices to prove the following bound.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{10}$ This is true even under local hedging, which uses independent randomness to commit to inspect-before-select or no-inspect for each item. The issue is that local hedging might not inspect an item even if it is inspect-before-select, and this decision depends on the hidden prices of other items.

Proposition B. 2 (cost analogue of Beyhaghi and Kleinberg (2019, Lemma 16)). In the nonobligatory inspection problem, the expected total of policy $\pi$ satisfies

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[C^{\pi}\right] \geq \mathbf{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W_{n}^{\pi}\right]
$$

As we show below, this result implies Theorem 3.4.
Alternative proof of Theorem 3.4. In light of Proposition B.2, it suffices to show

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W_{n}^{\pi}\right] \geq \mathbf{E}\left[\min _{n \in[N]} W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}}\right]
$$

Similarly to the proof of Theorem 3.4, we show this by replacing $\pi$-surrogate prices with NIsurrogate prices one-by-one. Specifically, it suffices to show that for each $n \in[N]$, we have

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{\ldots, W_{n-1}^{\pi}, W_{n}^{\pi}, W_{n+1}^{\mathrm{NI}}, \ldots\right\}\right] \geq \mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{\ldots, W_{n-1}^{\pi}, W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}}, W_{n+1}^{\mathrm{NI}}, \ldots\right\}\right]
$$

as chaining these inequalities together for all $n \in[N]$ yields (B.1). The above holds if for all $r \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\pi}, r\right\}\right] \geq \mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}}, r\right\}\right]
$$

By Definition B. 1 and Lemma 3.3, we have, as desired,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\pi}, r\right\}\right] & \geq \min \left\{\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\mathrm{OI}}, r\right\}\right], \min \left\{\mu_{n}, r\right\}\right\} \\
& =\min \left\{\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\mathrm{OI}}, r\right\}\right], \mu_{n}\right\} \\
& =\mathbf{E}\left[\min \left\{W_{n}^{\mathrm{NI}}, r\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

abstract:
We consider search problems with nonobligatory inspection and single-item or
combinatorial selection. A decision maker is presented with a number of items,
each of which contains an unknown price, and can pay an inspection cost to
observe the item's price before selecting it. Under single-item selection, the
decision maker must select one item; under combinatorial selection, the
decision maker must select a set of items that satisfies certain constraints.
In our nonobligatory inspection setting, the decision maker can select items
without first inspecting them. It is well-known that search with nonobligatory
inspection is harder than the well-studied obligatory inspection case, for
which the optimal policy for single-item selection (Weitzman, 1979) and
approximation algorithms for combinatorial selection (Singla, 2018) are known.
  We introduce a technique, local hedging, for constructing policies with good
approximation ratios in the nonobligatory inspection setting. Local hedging
transforms policies for the obligatory inspection setting into policies for the
nonobligatory inspection setting, at the cost of an extra factor in the
approximation ratio. The factor is instance-dependent but is at most 4/3. We
thus obtain the first approximation algorithms for a variety of combinatorial
selection problems, including matroid basis, matching, and facility location.
